text: English grammar lesson seven topic
reported speech this lesson will be an
introduction to the topic reported
speech is how we report another person's
words that is how we restate what
someone said the focus of this first
lesson will be on two questions what's
the difference between quoted speech and
reported speech when can we use say and
tell and to make it a little more
interesting I've chosen the theme of
birthdays I hope this will make it a
little more enjoyable to learn about
reported speech do you like birthdays I
like celebrating birthdays just not mine
so are you ready to get started with our
lesson on birthdays and reported speech
good let's begin point one what's the
difference between quoted speech and
reported speech well let me explain by
giving you an example I like birthday
what did Jennifer say we can answer that
question two different ways with quoted
speech Jennifer said I like birthdays or
with reported speech Jennifer said that
she liked birthdays quoted speech uses
the exact words of the speaker it's also
called direct speech reported speech
does not use the exact words of the
speaker it's also called indirect speech
quoted speech uses quotation marks they
go around the original words reported
speech does not use quotation marks look
at these examples of quoted in reported
speech do you see in quoted speech we
have quotation marks around the original
words those original words can be stated
at the end or at the beginning
inside those quotation marks we have a
period and commas just before the second
quotation mark we can name the speaker
at the beginning or at the end and if
it's at the end we can switch around the
reporting verb and the speaker Jennifer
said or said Jennifer note with a
pronoun we normally just say she said
not said she and in reported speech
there are no quotation marks the same
holds true for questions in quoted
speech we can name the speaker at the
beginning or at the end and we put
quotation marks around the original
words and the question mark it falls
within the quotation marks let's try an
exercise exercise one correct the
mistakes example what's wrong with the
statement my birthday is in March
Jennifer said the mistake is with the
quotation marks let's move them and put
them around the original words try
number one Jennifer asked when is your
birthday do you see the mistake this is
quoted speech we need quotation marks
around the original words like this
number two Jennifer told us that her
birthday is in March do you see the
mistake there should be no quotation
marks this is reported speech three my
daughter's birthday is in May Jennifer
said do you see the mistake
this is direct speech quoted speech use
quotation marks and do not use a - for
my daughter will be - said Jennifer do
you see the mistake it's a small one we
need a comma place it right before the
second quotation mark point - when can
we use say and tell the two most common
reporting verbs are probably safe and
tell let's talk about each of them both
say and tell our reporting verbs we
often used tell if we named the speaker
and the listener for example she told us
that she's over 30 we can use say to
name the listener - but it's not as
common she said to us that she's over 30
that's okay she told us that she's over
30 this is more natural please note if
you use say to name the speaker and the
listener used - don't use - after tell
here are two examples she said to us
that she's over 30 she told us that
she's over 30 do you see the difference
two very common structures for reported
statements then are the following
who + said + that she said that she's
over 30 you can also leave that out
she said she's over 30 + who + told +
whom + that she told us that she's over
30 again you can leave out that she told
us she's over 30
let me also try to help you by sharing
some differences that I see between say
and tell we you say for greetings and
farewells for example he said hello to
us we say good morning to our teacher
every day they said goodbye note with
these greetings and farewells if you
name the listener the listener goes
after what is said he said hello to us
we also use save for giving yes/no
answers and stating polite phrases for
example she said yes they always say no
we say bless you after someone sneezes
we tend to use tell for facts and pieces
of information for example he told us
his age you told them a story she told
me how to find the cafe it would sound a
bit strange to change told to said in
these sentences he said to us his age
you said to them a story she said to me
how to find the cafe a little awkward so
tell is best for facts and pieces of
information especially long pieces of
information are you ready for another
exercise
exercise - juice say or tell let's start
with an example
Alex smiled when he saw the present and

listener is not named and thanks is one
of those polite phrases the correct
choice is said we say thanks just like
we say sorry and excuse me
